On 1/27/12 12:08 AM, ngzikai92 wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I would like to know more about how the frontier processes
> redirection (i.e. what is happening when URI is being redirected, how
> does Heritrix knows that a URI is being redirected) and also is there
> a difference on how Heritrix process redirection between different
> forms of redirection (i.e. server side, javascripts, and maybe
> iframes?)
>
> I tried reading some Heritrix documentations but have not found the
> answer yet.

An HTTP redirection code is treated as a new URI discovered via the 
first. The new URI will have a 'hops-path' (also called pathFromSeed in 
the source code) that ends with a 'R' character, and its 'via' 
(immediate predecessor) URI will be the one that redirected to it.

The usual scoping rules will, via the TransclusionDecideRule, tend to 
rule such URIs in, as long as the number of 'R' hops in a row aren't too 
high. However, the overall hop-counting of the TooManyHopsDecideRule 
treats these 'R' hops the same as any others. That is, 2 or 3 in a row 
are treated as 2-3 hops from the seed URI.

A <META> refresh in HTML is handled the same way, as an 'R' discovered 
outlink. (The most notable difference from the HTTP redirect case is 
that an HTTP redirect will only yield one other URI, whereas the rest of 
the HTML after the refresh will yield whatever other outlinks are there 
as well.)

A Javascript redirect will only be discovered when the URI is findable 
via our crude pattern-based Javascript link-extraction. In such a case, 
the outlink is of 'X'speculative type, because we don't analyze the 
Javascript to see how it's triggering the load (or whether it is loading 
something into an embedded region or replacing the main page).

An <IFRAME SRC> is considered an outlink of 'E'mbed type, as it appears 
inline on the page and is required to render the original page. It 
counts as an extra hop, but is also usually ruled-in by the 
TransclusionDecideRule.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon
